title: Hopf algebras up to homotopy and the Bockstein spectral sequence

title_detail.value: Hopf algebras up to homotopy and the Bockstein spectral sequence

summary:
Anick proved that every q-mild Hopf algebra up to homotopy is isomorphic to a
primitively-generated chain Hopf algebra. We provide a new proof, that involves
extensive use of the Bockstein spectral sequence.

summary_detail.value:
Anick proved that every q-mild Hopf algebra up to homotopy is isomorphic to a
primitively-generated chain Hopf algebra. We provide a new proof, that involves
extensive use of the Bockstein spectral sequence.

Algebraic & Geometric Topology
Volume 5 (2005) 119–128
Published: 7 February 2005

119

ATG

Hopf algebras up to homotopy and the
Bockstein spectral sequence
Jonathan Scott
Abstract Anick proved that every q -mild Hopf algebra up to homotopy
is isomorphic to a primitively-generated chain Hopf algebra. We provide a
new proof, that involves extensive use of the Bockstein spectral sequence.
AMS Classification 16W30; 57T05, 55T99
Keywords Hopf algebras, Bockstein spectral sequence

1

Introduction

Let R be a subring of the rationals containing 1/2. A Hopf algebra up to homotopy, or Hah, is an augmented chain R-algebra A, equipped with an algebra
morphism ∆ : A → A ⊗ A that is homotopy-coassociative and homotopycocommutative. We will suppose that the augmentation provides a strict counit for ∆. A Hah morphism is an algebra morphism that commutes with the
diagonals up to chain algebra homotopy.
The aim of this paper is to present an alternate proof of the following theorem
of D. Anick.
Anick's Theorem [2, Theorem 5.6] Let ρ > 2 be the least non-invertible
prime in R, and let q ≥ 1. If A is a Hah whose underlying algebra is free and
generated by the range of dimensions q through qρ − 1, inclusive, then A is
isomorphic as a Hah to a primitively-generated chain Hopf algebra.
Anick's theorem was one of the more important recent developments in rational
homotopy theory. Applied to the Adams-Hilton model of a space X , it allows
rational homotopy theorists to apply their techniques to decidedly non-rational
problems. Indeed, as outlined in [4], the singular cochain complex C ∗ (X; R) is
then weakly equivalent to a commutative cochain algebra that plays the role
of the algebra of polynomial differential forms, AP L (X), in rational homotopy
theory.
c Geometry & Topology Publications

 Jonathan Scott

120

The proof provided by Anick is quite technical, and involves constructing a
"partial inverse" to the diagonal map. In the present paper, the author proposes
a proof that uses nothing more than the Bockstein spectral sequence as detailed
in Browder [3], and the results on Hopf algebras from Milnor and Moore [5].
The key to the new proof of Anick's theorem is Theorem 1.1 below, where we
consider the result of adjoining a free algebra variable to a primitively-generated
chain Hopf algebra. First we introduce some terminology. A free monogenic
extension of a chain algebra A is a chain algebra (A ∐ T (x), dx = b) where ∐
denotes the free product of algebras, b ∈ Adeg x−1 is a cycle, and T (x) is the
tensor algebra on the graded module R{x}. If A is a cocommutative chain Hopf
algebra, then a free monogenic extension of Hopf algebras up to homotopy is a
free monogenic extension of A along with a homotopy-coassociative, homotopycocommutative choice of reduced diagonal Φ ∈ (A⊗A)deg x for x. A good reference for the homotopy theory of chain algebras is Anick's paper [2]. Effectively,
to say that Φ is a "homotopy-coassociative" and "homotopy-cocommutative"
choice means that there exist elements f ∈ A ⊗ A ⊗ A and g ∈ A ⊗ A such that
(∆ ⊗ 1 + 1 ⊗ ∆)Φ = df and (τ − 1)Φ = dg . If Φ = 0 then we call the extension
trivial. An isomorphism of extensions

is a chain algebra morphism that restricts to the identity on A, that satisfies
θ(x)−x ∈ A, and that commutes with diagonals up to a chain algebra homotopy
vanishing on A.
Recall that a graded algebra A is called q -reduced if An = 0 for 0 < n < q .
Theorem 1.1 Let (A, ∂) be a connected, primitively generated, q -reduced,
R-free chain Hopf algebra of finite type. Suppose A → A ∐ T (x) is a free
extension of Hopf algebras up to homotopy, with ∂x primitive. If deg x < qρ,
then the extension is isomorphic to the trivial one.
Theorem 1.1 will be proved in Section 2.
Proof of Anick's Theorem Let A = T V be a Hopf algebra up to homotopy.
Let {vj } be a well-ordered basis of V , where we have chosen an ordering such
that deg vi < deg vj implies that i < j . Suppose inductively that A(i−1) =
T (v1 , . . . vi−1 ) is a primitively generated Hopf algebra. Adding the generator
vi yields the chain algebra extension
A(i−1) → A(i−1) ∐ T (vi )

 Hopf algebras up to homotopy and the BSS

121

where ∆v
Lemma 2.2 below, Hm (P (A(i−1) ⊗ Zp )) ∼
= P Hm (A(i−1) ⊗ Zp ) if m < qρ, for all
primes p in R. Since P (A(i−1) ⊗ Zp ) = P (A(i−1) ) ⊗ Zp in these degrees, we
conclude that Hm (P A(i−1) ) ∼
= P Hm (A(i−1) ), and so we may choose ∂vi to be
primitive in P (A(i−1) ). Now we may apply Theorem 1.1.
Remark 1.2 Anick assumes a homotopy counit, but then goes on to show
that every Hah is isomorphic to one with a strict counit [2, Lemma 5.4].
We use the usual definitions for chain algebras, coalgebras, Hopf algebras, and
homotopies of chain algebra morphisms [2, Section 2]. Algebras are assumed
to be connected and augmented to the ground ring. The linear dual of a chain
complex V is denoted V ∗ .
The author would like to take this opportunity to thank Jean-Claude Thomas
and Jim Stasheff, for useful comments and suggestions, as well as the referee,
whose recommendations led to a major reworking of the article. The end result
is more elementary, less technical, more accessible, and just plain better.

2

The Proof of Theorem 1.1

Let p be an odd prime, and denote by Zp the field of integers modulo p. We
prove a proposition about cocommutative extensions of Hopf algebras over Zp .
We then prove several lemmas that allow us to manage the Bockstein spectral
sequence, before proving the inductive step, Proposition 2.8. We finish the
section with the proof of Theorem 1.1 proper.
We begin by quickly reviewing some facts about Hopf algebras, gleaned from the
standard reference of Milnor and Moore [5]. Let C be a connected, associative,
coassociative, graded Hopf algebra with multiplication μ : C ⊗C → C , diagonal
∆ : C → C ⊗ C and augmentation ε : C → R. Let I(C) = ker ε. The space of
 ̄ : I(C) →
indecomposables of C is the quotient I(C)/μ(I(C) ⊗ I(C)). Let ∆
 ̄ = ∆c − c ⊗ 1 − 1 ⊗ c.
I(C) ⊗ I(C) be the reduced diagonal, defined by ∆c

Then P (C) = ker ∆ is the subspace of primitive elements. The natural map
I(C) → Q(C) restricts to define a map P (C) → Q(C), natural with respect to
morphisms of Hopf algebras.
Denote by T C(V ) the tensor coalgebra on V . As a graded module, T C(V ) =
T (V ) = ⊕n≥0 V ⊗n . Elements of V ⊗n are traditionally denoted [v1 | * * * |vn ]. The

While the following proposition likely qualifies as folklore, we provide a proof
nonetheless.
Proposition 2.1 Let A be a connected, primitively-generated Hopf algebra
of finite type over Zp . Suppose that
A → A ∐ T (x)
is a coassociative and cocommutative extension. If A is (r − 1)-connected and
deg(x) < rp, then A ∐ T (x) is primitively generated.
Proof Set B = A∐T (x). Dualize the extension A → B to obtain a morphism
of connected commutative Hopf algebras f : B ∗ → A∗ . It suffices to show that
the natural morphism P (B ∗ ) → Q(B ∗ ) is injective. Let ξ : B ∗ → B ∗ be the
Frobenius map defined by ξ(x) = xp . Then ξB ∗ is a sub Hopf algebra of B ∗ .
By [5, Proposition 4.21], there is an exact sequence
0 → P (ξB ∗ ) → P (B ∗ ) → Q(B ∗ )
so it suffices to show that P (ξB ∗ ) = 0.

a splitting of the natural projection π : I(A) → V . Extend σ to a splitting
τ : W → B of ρ : I(B) → W . Then σ and τ extend to algebra epimorphisms

so α = 0. Since P (τ ∗ ) is a monomorphism, bp = 0 and the result follows.
Let A be a chain Hopf algebra over Zp ; that is, A is simultaneously a Hopf
algebra and a chain complex, such that the differential ∂ is both a derivation and
a coderivation. Then H(A) is naturally a Hopf algebra. Let iA : P (A) → A be
the natural inclusion of the primitive subspace. Then H(iA ) : H(P A) → H(A)
factors through the inclusion iH(A) : P H(A) → H(A) to yield a morphism
j : H(P A) → P H(A).
Let A be a chain Hopf algebra such that ∂ = 0 on A<n . If a ∈ An is not a
cycle, then a is indecomposable, and ∂a is primitive.
Let B be a connected, primitively-generated Hopf algebra of finite type over
Zp . Since pth powers vanish in B ∗ , they also vanish in the commutative Hopf
algebra H(B ∗ ) = H(B)∗ . By [5, Proposition 4.20], it follows that H(B) is
primitively generated.

isomorphism in degrees < qp.

Example 2.3 Consider the commutative, primitively-generated Hopf algebra
over Zp , A = Zp [x] ⊗ ∧(y), with deg x = 2n, and n ≥ 1. The differential is the
2
derivation determined by the rule ∂x = y . Then P A = Zp {y, x, xp , xp , . . .}. It
2
follows that H(P A) = Zp {xp , xp , . . .}. On the other hand, H(A) = Zp [xp ] ⊗

to be surjective in degree 2np − 1.
Example 2.4 Let B = ∧(x) ⊗ Zp [y], with deg x = 2n + 1. The differential
2
is given by ∂x = y . Then P B = Zp {x, y, y p , y p , . . .}, and so H(P B) =
2
Zp {y p , y p , . . .}. Meanwhile, H(B) = 0, so P H(B) = 0. Therefore j :
H(P B) → P H(B) is not injective.
Let A be a connected primitively-generated Hopf algebra of finite type over
Z(p) , the ring of integers localized at p. Recall from [3] that the Bockstein
spectral sequence of A in homology modulo p, denoted (E r , β r ), is a spectral
sequence of primitively-generated Hopf algebras over Zp that converges

torsion
We now introduce some notation to avoid confusion when following elements
up and down the terms of the spectral sequence. Let C be a chain complex,
and denote by E r its Bockstein spectral sequence modulo p. If x ∈ C is a
cycle modulo p that survives to the r th term of the spectral sequence, then we
denote its equivalence class in E r by [x]r . In particular, [x]2 = [[x]1 ], and so
on.
The following elementary lemma clarifies what it means for one element to be
the higher Bockstein of another.
Algebraic & Geometric Topology, Volume 5 (2005)

 Hopf algebras up to homotopy and the BSS

125

Lemma 2.5 Let C be a chain complex and denote by E r the r th term of
the Bockstein spectral sequence of C modulo p. Suppose ar , br ∈ E r satisfy
β r ar = br . Suppose further that a, b ∈ C represent ar and br , respectively.
That is, a and b are cycles modulo p that survive to E r , where [a]r = ar and
[b]r = br . Then there exist c, e ∈ C such that d(a + pc) = pr (b + pe).
Proof We proceed by induction on r. For r = 1, if a is a cycle modulo p,
then da = px for some x ∈ C . By definition, β 1 [a]1 = [x]1 , so [x]1 = [b]1 .
Thus there exist elements c, e ∈ C such that x = b + pe − dc. Therefore
da = px = pb + p2 e − d(pc) and the statement holds, grounding the induction.
Assume that the lemma is true for r = k − 1 for some k ≥ 2, and suppose
that β k [a]k = [b]k . Since a survives to the k th term of the spectral sequence,
β k−1 [a]k−1 = 0. Applying the inductive hypothesis, we find that there exist
elements f, g ∈ C such that d(a + pf ) = pk g . By definition, β k [a]k = [g]k .
Thus [g]k = [b]k , so [g − b]k = 0, that is, there exists some y ∈ C that survives
to E k−1 , where [g − b]k−1 = β k−1 [y]k−1 . By the inductive hypothesis, there
exist elements z, e ∈ C such that d(y + pz) = pk−1 (g − b − pe). Therefore
d(a + pf ) = pk g = pk b + pk+1 e + d(py + p2 z). Rearranging, we find that
d(a + p(f − y − pz)) = pk (b + pe). Set c = f − y − pz to complete the inductive
step and the proof.
Corollary 2.6 If [b′ ]r = [b′ ]r in E r , then there exist elements e, f ∈ C such
that pr−1 b′ = pr−1 b′′ + pr e + df .
Proof Since [b′ ]r = [b′′ ]r , there exists a ∈ C such that β r−1 [a]r−1 = [b′ −
b′′ ]r−1 . Apply Lemma 2.5.

Proof of Theorem 1.1 Consider C = ΩA/Ω≥3 A, where Ω(−) is the Adams
cobar construction [1]. Since A is finite type, Hn−2 (C) is a finitely generated
R-module. We note that R is a principal ideal domain, so there is a finite list
of primes p for which Hn−2 (C) contains p-torsion. For each of those primes,
we make the following argument.
 ̄ and let f and g be the relevant homotopies. Since ∂x is primitive,
Let Φ = ∆x,
it follows that ∂Φ = 0. Apply Proposition 2.8. Then [Φ] ∈ Hn−2 (C) and

[Φ] = pr [Φr ] for all r. Since Hn−2 (C) is finitely generated, it follows that
 ̄ = Φ + ∂Ψ.
[Φ] = 0. Therefore there exist Ψ ∈ A ⊗ A and a ∈ A such that ∆a
Define
 ̄ = Φ) → (A ∐ T (x), ∆x
 ̄ = 0)
θ : (A ∐ T (x), ∆x
by θ|A = 1A and θ(x) = x + a. Then θ is an isomorphism of chain algebras
that commutes with the diagonals up to homotopy.
